key_title: Key to the species of Clematis

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Ranunculaceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Ranunculaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Walsh, N.G. (1996). Ranunculaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Flowers unisexual (but female flowers sometimes with staminodes); leaves ternate to triternate, rarely simple; plants evergreen
Flowers bisexual; leaves pinnate; plants deciduous
Anthers with a sterile apical appendage (short in C. glycinoides); leaves mostly once-ternate, widest ultimate leaflets mostly more than 15 mm wide, margins entire or toothed
Anthers without a sterile apical appendage; leaves mostly biternate to triternate, ultimate leaflets no more than c. 12 mm wide, margins entire or lobed
Anther appendage pointed, 1 mm long or more; anthers 2–3.5 mm long; leaflets usually dull, with toothed margins; widespread vine of wet forests
Anther appendage blunt, c. 0.5 mm long; anthers c. 1.5 mm long; leaflets glossy, with entire (very rarely obscurely toothed) margins; east of Melbourne only
Leaflets more than 12, up to 4.5 cm long, lobed or entire
Leaflets 9(–12), up to 6 cm long, rarely lobed
Leaflets 18–36, oblong to obovate, terminal leaflet 0. 5–1.5(–2.5) cm long; drier areas in the east
Leaflets 12–15, narrow-ovate to oblong, terminal leaflet 1.2–4.5 cm long; mostly in southern and western Victoria
Sepals pubescent along margins of lower surface, elsewhere sparsely pubescent or glabrous; leaflets 12–15
Sepals densely pubescent on both upper and lower surfaces; leaflets usually 5
